Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Nancy Chen is "Elucidating the genomic and phenotypic basis of contemporary evolution in Florida Scrub-Jays." The host institution for this fellowship is the University of California, Davis, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Graham Coop.

Recent studies have demonstrated evolution on ecological timescales (that is, shorter than previously thought) in a number of different organisms. Studying contemporary evolution is the only way to directly test many fundamental questions in evolutionary biology, such as the persistence of high levels of genetic variation in the presence of selection. Several theories seeking to explain this long-standing paradox have been proposed; however, empirical validations of these predictions are rare in natural populations because they require a particular type of biological collection: archived DNA samples with associated phenotypic and fitness measures for several thousand individuals over multiple generations. Despite increasing interest in measuring evolution in real-time and increasing availability of suitable datasets, rigorous methods for inferring natural selection from these types of data are lacking. Needed is the development of new methods that leverage longitudinal population samples and pedigree information to test for selection on complex traits at different life-history stages. This powerful framework for studying contemporary evolution further increases the insights that can be gained from biological collections. The fellowship research develops and applies novel analytical methods to study short-term selection on complex traits in the Florida Scrub-Jay (Aphelocoma coerulescens), using a unique collection of archived blood and DNA samples at the Cornell Museum of Vertebrates as well as associated demographic and ecological data stored at Archbold Biological Station. Application of these methods to the Florida Scrub-Jays improves our understanding of the importance of selection in maintaining genetic variation in natural populations.

Training goals include gaining the computational and quantitative skills necessary to develop and apply novel population genetics and statistical genetics methods. Broader impacts involve development of open-source software, undergraduate training in interdisciplinary research, and communication of research findings to the general public as well as government and conservation agencies. The Florida Scrub-Jay is one of the rarest birds in North America, and results from this work promise to inform conservation efforts for this species. Results are also being disseminated via educational outreach activities and the Cornell Lab of Ornithology?s communication outlets to increase public understanding of evolutionary processes operating within populations in ecological time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studying contemporary evolution provides a unique opportunity to directly test many fundamental questions in evolutionary biology and is directly relevant for conserving declining species in the face of habitat loss and climate change. While much attention has been given to phenotypic evolution on ecological timescales, technological challenges and limited sampling of temporal genomic data from natural populations have left a gap in knowledge about short-term evolutionary dynamics at the genomic level. This lack of knowledge prevents us from deeply understanding the adaptive potential of natural populations and hinders our ability to predict evolutionary trajectories. Indeed, measuring evolution of natural populations in real-time remains challenging, and systems with sufficient data to study contemporary evolution are rare. The best opportunities to study contemporary evolution in nature come from a few long-term studies that have phenotypic and fitness measures for thousands of individuals on a pedigree. This fellowship funded a number of projects on contemporary evolution in the Florida Scrub-Jay (Aphelocoma coerulescens; hereafter FSJ).

The FSJ is an iconic species on the U.S. Endangered Species List and a classic model in behavioral ecology and population biology. A population of individually-marked FSJs at Archbold Biological Station has been studied since 1969, resulting in detailed life histories and genomic data for ~4,000 jays on one of the most accurate and extensive pedigrees for any wild vertebrate species. This near-complete sampling of the entire study population for over a decade provides an unprecedented ability to quantify the contributions of different evolutionary forces in shaping patterns of genomic variation through space and time.

My first postdoctoral research project investigated the genomic consequences of limited dispersal in the FSJ. Geographically limited dispersal often results in a pattern of spatial genetic structure known as isolation-by-distance. Understanding the timescales over which dispersal and genetic drift act to affect the distribution of alleles across space is critical for advancing studies of local adaptation and speciation. Isolation-by-distance is a commonly observed pattern in nature, yet empirically demonstrating how limited dispersal generates this pattern remains challenging because few systems have direct measures of individual dispersal distances as well as genomic and pedigree data. We found isolation-by-distance on an extremely fine spatial scale (~10 km), with a stronger signal of isolation-by-distance in males compared to females. Using the pedigree, we showed how various genealogical relationships contribute to the observed pattern of isolation-by-distance. We used simulations to show that limited dispersal can generate a pattern of strong isolation-by-distance over just a few generations. This work provided a comprehensive understanding of how dispersal shapes patterns of genetic diversity over short spatial scales.

As an extension of the isolation-by-distance project, we investigated the effect of limited dispersal on levels of inbreeding within our study population. Natal dispersal and mate choice are important determinants of levels of inbreeding in natural populations, which in turn affect genetic diversity and fitness. Previous work in our study population showed evidence of inbreeding depression at multiple life history stages, which often results in selection for inbreeding avoidance. We tested for inbreeding avoidance but instead found evidence that individuals prefer to mate with relatives. We demonstrated that the observed inbreeding preference is due to limited dispersal. This project demonstrates how a strong preference for short dispersal distances can result in increased inbreeding in a natural population.

Finally, I directly characterized the relative roles of different evolutionary processes in shaping patterns of genetic variation through time, a central goal of population genetics. Every population has a true underlying pedigree, which encodes the number of offspring each individual contributes to future generations and therefore constrains how genetic drift can act. Using gene dropping simulations to model drift on the known pedigree, I estimated expected individual genetic contributions over time for all adults in our population from 1990-2013 and quantified the genetic contribution of recent immigrants over time. I identified 11 loci whose frequency dynamics were driven by short-term selection after appropriately accounting for drift and gene flow. Using models that account for changes in population size, I partitioned the proportion of allele frequency change through time due to gene flow and drift. This work quantifies the roles of gene flow and drift in governing allele frequency change over time, and demonstrates that selection can be strong enough to cause large allele frequency shifts over short timescales.

In addition to contributing to our understanding of how natural populations evolve over short timescales, this fellowship also supported efforts to increase diversity and inclusion in the STEM workforce. I help lead a women in science group at UC Davis and I recently joined the Diversity and Inclusion Committee for the American Ornithology Society. In 2017, I co-organized a symposium on increasing diversity in ornithology at the American Ornithology Society Conference.
